column1: Banyuwangi Regency is a regency (Indonesian: kabupaten) of East Java province in Indonesia. The regency is located at the easternmost end of Java Island. It serves as a port between Java and Bali. It is surrounded by mountains and forests to the west; by sea to the east and south. Banyuwangi is separated by the Strait of Bali from Bali. With an area of 5
column3: this regency is the largest in Java. The regency is a tourist destination
column4: and subject to ongoing development as an international tourist destination with relevant infrastructure. Banyuwangi regency has been declared a taman bumi (earth park)
column5: or national geological park (Geopark) in 2018.It had a population of 1
column7: 791 according to the 2000 Census; by the 2010 Census it had risen to 1
column9: 078; and the latest official estimate (for January 2014) is 1
column11: 788. The city of Banyuwangi is the administrative capital. The name Banyuwangi is Javanese for "fragrant water"
column12: connected to the Javanese folklore of Sri Tanjung.

column1: One Banyuwangi native group is the Osing community which has a Hindu culture although they can be considered as a Javanese sub-ethnic group. They live mainly in the central part of Banyuwangi and they sometimes consider themselves as Majapahit descendants. Other groups are Javanese (living mostly in the south and west)
column2: Madurese (mainly in the north and coastal area) and Balinese (scattered but more concentrated in the east). Other smaller groups include Chinese

column1: Once known as Blambangan (or its variation: Balambangan and Balumbungan)
column2: it was a vassal of the Majapahit Kingdom and a regional trade centre. After the Majapahit Kingdom ceased to exist
column3: it became an independent kingdom and
column5: the last Hindu kingdom of Java. In order to defend itself from the troops of the Sultanate of Demak
column7: Blambangan asked for help from Balinese kings
column8: which caused it to lose its independence to Balinese kingdoms. During this time Blambangan was deeply influenced by Balinese culture. After around 150 years of Balinese occupation
column9: the Sultanate of Mataram gained control of the territory and renamed it Banyuwangi. Later
column10: it was part of the Mataram territory controlled by the VOC (1770). During the expansion of plantations in the 19th century
column11: many parts of Banyuwangi were planted with coffee and sugar cane
column12: which feature its landscape even now. The Chinese and Arabs came mostly during this period.

column1: Banyuwangi people are known for their combination of Islamic and pre-Islamic tradition.

column2: a witchhunt in Banyuwangi against alleged sorcerers spiraled into widespread riots and violence. In addition to alleged sorcerers
column3: Islamic clerics were also targeted and killed
column4: Nahdlatul Ulama members were murdered by rioters.

column1: This is a Banyuwangi-typical dance which performed by a woman and along with simple music like violin
column4: kendhang and sometimes with keyboard as result of modern influence. It is performed during night until dawn particularly in parties.

column1: Damarwulan is a legendary hero who features in traditional theatre art which has been developed since the 19th century in Banyuwangi. It is a combination of Balinese
column2: Javanese and local cultures. Balinese influences can be seen in its performers' costumes and instruments. Meanwhile
column3: Javanese influences is in its "lakon" or stories as well as language in dialogues. It is distinct from the Balinese Janger.

column1: Banyuwangi International Airport at Blimbingsari serves the regency
column2: Banyuwangi city and surrounding area of East Java. Banyuwangi can be reached by road and rail from Surabaya or by ferry from Bali.

column1: Many European tourists visiting Bali come to Banyuwangi to surf in Plengkung and dive in Tabuhan Island. Ferries from Bali arrive at the port of Ketapang
column2: some 8 km to the north of Banyuwangi city. Plekung Beach is also known as G-Land or green land have 3 types of waves up to 6 to 8 meters tall.

column1: Banyuwangi International Surfing Competition 2014This was the second time competition after the 2012 competition. 23–25 May 2014 competition is followed by at least 15 countries in Pantai Pulau Merah (Red Island Beach) which has 4 meters height and 400 meters long of waves.

column2: we can see tosca lake crater and traditional sulphur mining which the sulphur bunch mobilization still use human to hike and down to the crater.
besides see the animals we can surf at G-Land/Plengkung with Money Trees

Sukamade Turtle Breeding Station regularly releases baby marine turtles to open ocean. 4 of 6 kind of turtles can be found in Indonesia regularly visit Sukamade to put their eggs. Penyu Hijau (Chelonia mydas) visit the Sukamade Beach almost everynight
column3: Penyu Lekang (Lepidochelys olivacea) visit in March to June
column4: Penyu Belimbing (Dermochelys coriacea) put the egg every 4 years in June to September and the scare Penyu Sisik (Eremochelys olivacea) very seldom to visit the beach.WaterfallsVisitors may be interested to find several waterfalls in one locality.  Opened formally in 2014
column5: there are a number of waterfalls in Kampung Anyar (New Village)
column7: around 15 kilometers from Banyuwangi on the way to Mount Ijen. There are 3 waterfalls near to each other known as the "Triple Waterfall" to be found 10 minutes walk down the stairs from a parking area. Or about 300 meters along the river

column1: Banyuwangi has a temperate tropical and wet dry climate
column2: similar to Banyuwangi's dry season start from May until October
column3: and the rest is wet season. in 2013
column4: Banyuwangi's highest average temperature is on October with 28.2 °C and lowest average temperature is on April with 24.8 °C

column1: The forest and river in Banyuwangi is well-preserved
column2: says the Indonesia Dragonfly Society because they found 3 dragonfly species which only can live in good environment.Nevertheless
column3: there are local controversies in the Regency over the impact of gold mining activities in the locality of Tumpang Pitu village.  In 2006
column4: the Banywangi regency administration granted a mining licence to one company
column6: which later transferred the licence to another company.  However
column7: the local community had expressed concern about gold mining activities as early as 1997.  The issues partly related to the protection of the area around a local Hindu temple
column9: and partly related to local community views about the economic and social impact of the mining.
